The IM API reference is split in two main parts: functions and chains. Functions are IM API calls that can be called directly. For example:

im.show(element); if (im.isString('mystring')) alert('i am a string');

Chains are functions that can be used when 'inside a chain'. Chains work exactly the same as in jQuery. Please consider the following code snippet:

// to demonstrate how chaining works we break up each step: var chain = im(element); // create chain chain.show(); // using im.chains.show instead of im.show chain = chain.find('a.button'); // find all ancors with class button and update the chain. chain.bind('click', function(){ alert('anchor button got clicked'); }); // but to utilize the power of chaining, the above is better written as: im(element).show().find('a.button').bind('click', function(){ alert('anchor button got clicked'); });

An example of a bit more advanced chaining:

/* This code will: - find all elements with class widget - show them - bind a click handler on each of them - find all spans of each widget - set a border on the spans - set the chain back to the widgets (end) - append a div to each of the widgets */ im('.widget').show().bind('click', function(){ im(this).hide(); }).find('span').css({ border : '1px solid red' }).end().append('<div>...</div>');
